tweet: This is my version of an overlay "chart crime", but I can't help but see the uncanny resemblance.  Going back to watch all 10 seasons to adjust my 2021 S&P 500 target.

Here's the long-term base ($TAN/$SPY).  Can it stabilize at higher levels & resume to the upside? or does it fizzle out like rally attempts over the last decade?  Given the length of the base, I'd argue this is more sustainable. than past attempts. Doesn't mean drawdown is done.
QQQ down 5% after news broke that it will not be added to the S&P 500.

For today's chart crime I overlayed the inverted WIG Index (Poland) and the S&P 500 VIX Index.  Does Poland hold the key to volatility in the US?   Just because stuff looks the same doesn't mean you can do anything useful with it.

A lot of the country indexes I discussed in this post a couple weeks ago are still working through overhead supply at their respective resistance levels.  Here's an updated chart of the S&P 500 as of yesterday's close. Breaking 2,940 would be significant.
Woah, for $5 I can own 1.6% of Apple?  Updates LinkedIn to business owner.

A close above the 10-month moving average and 200-day moving average this week would get basic trend-following systems long again after selling at the end of February.  At least for the R3K and S&P 500. IWM not so far, and QQQ already above it last month.

Before we start with the "too far too fast" comments on Amazon and Netflix, I'd like to remind you that both stocks have gone absolutely nowhere for nearly 2 years.  If you're gonna fade them longer-term, you need a stronger argument than that.
A lot of these country ETFs trading like they'll never outperform again relative to the S&P 500. $EWA $SPY  But, I guess if the whole world goes to zero it doesn't matter who gets there first.

For the first time in a while, longs have a clear level to trade against.  For the S&P 500 it's the December lows. For Mid/Small-Caps it's the 2016 lows.  Add some confirmed bullish momentum divergences to that and we might have the start of a little counter-trend rally.
A close above the March 12th lows would be the first CONFIRMED bullish momentum divergence in the S&P 500 since this decline began.

Those are things that continued.  As for things that may have caught some off guard as the baby gets thrown out with the bath water...maybe GDX vs SPY?  Wasn't a decisive uptrend, but wasn't a downtrend either. Messy at best. Sharp moves in both directions now.

Watching closely this week to see if prices of the major indices close below their January highs and confirm the many bearish divergences we're seeing.  Although this would be a signal of near-term weakness, as long as the S&P is above 2,950 then structurally things are intact.

Just go through the S&P 1500 by sector, or alphabetical order, or however you wanna do it and you'll find plenty of opportunity.  If you do it regularly the trends that matter will smack you in the face.

Last year some of the largest stocks weren't participating, so that was bearish.  Today the complaint is that Apple, Microsoft, etc. are up too much, make up too much of the index, and it can't continue.  Grateful so many think this way, preserves our edge of putting in the work.

This chart is just as relevant as when I posted it about a month ago.  Mobile Payments stocks are looking to break out on an absolute basis, which should re-accelerate their trend vs the broader market. $IPAY $SPY
Nice, but what if you rented in a low cost of living city and reinvested the difference in the S&P 500?  Could retire by 40, depending on how many books you read each week.  Kidding, congrats Morgan!

When they remove GE from the S&P 500 and replace it with Palladium, then I'll start to worry.   With that said, I don't attend many cocktail parties these days. I spend whatever free time I have on Twitter warning people of reckless central bank policies and negative rates.

You can frame things however you'd like to depending on the thesis you're presenting.  The S&P 500 is up ~275 points since the June low.  Or  The S&P 500 is down ~50 points from its highs and down for a third day in a row.  Both are facts but what's your interpretation & context?

Interesting divergence between an Equally-Weighted Index of the 10 largest S&P 500 stocks and the S&P 500, which is making all-time highs.  The two move together over the long-term, so will the largest stocks play catch-up again? $SPY $SPX

Some interesting relationships that I don't see get much play are things like the S&P Small-Cap 600 Growth / S&P 500 Growth ratio breaking down to its lowest levels since 2010.  You can favor growth, but which market-cap segment are you going to be in?

Triple top? More like triple STOP.  Triple tops don't confirm until prices break the lowest low between them. That wouldn't happen until the S&P is down 20% and breaking the December lows.  The Dow is simply "below resistance" right now.
When your own two headlines can't even agree on the reason for the Dow's 7 point gain.

Exploration & Production subsector stabilizing relative to the S&P 500.  Is this part of a larger reversal? or a counter-trend move within the context of a long-term downtrend?  I'm leaning toward the latter, but that doesn't mean we can't see a 10% rally first.

Yep, I mentioned the Yen exposure in there.  Luckily we live in a world where we can sell an orange and buy an apple.   Nothing says we can't trade two vehicles that have different construction, we just have to be aware of the currency exposure & incorporate it into our analysis.

Check out USMV / SPY. I'd rather be erring on the long side of this pair with a rising 200-day and momentum in a bullish range.   Looks like a retest of the breakout area before heading higher.  Guess we'll see what happens =)

One of the best tools on  is the ability to look at an ETFs components and quickly see their weighting, returns, and attribution.  I see the Dow is lagging today, but why?  In a click of a button I can see that DWDP, BA, and GS are weighing on the Index.

I hear ya.  YouTubers have the same issue due to the lack of transparency from Google about changes to the algorithm / platform overall.   Many accept it's out of their control, diversify across platforms/distribution channels, and focus on creating the best content they can.

How many times have we heard "Growth / Value has peaked".   One could argue that the S&P Smallcap 600 Growth / Value ratio just broke out of a 3-year base 6 months ago.  Market generalizations rarely tell the whole story.
Does this Aerospace & Defense Sector / S&P 500 look like a top or a bottom?  Can the market rally with this former market leader hitting 52-week lows?

A lot of hubbub about $AAPL today. To me it's simple. If it's gonna bounce, it'll be from current levels with a bullish momentum divergence being confirmed if prices close above ~ 171.  We've had every reason to be short since 208 broke.  Now a neutral/long bias makes sense.

Going thru the S&P 500 and listing out names that are showing relative strength and near their risk management level. When the selling subsides, they'll be the ones to lead.  Don't want to list out names where the reward/risk isn't skewed in our favor. Good for info purposes tho.
$AAPL may not move several percent a day like some other tech names, but continues to look great. Target remains up near 208. $QQQ

Agreed. Depending on when you run the numbers and the correlation formula timeframe you use, you'll get mixed results.  For me I just look at it for confirmation/divergence of risk appetite  i.e. SPX  4-month highs and Yen at 6-month lows. Both pointing to appetite not aversion.

If you lag one variable, limit the timeframe, and ignore the magnitude of change, you can make anything look like a linear relationship.  A 2-3% change in the balance sheet caused a 10% change in the S&P 500?  Don't know what these type of charts are trying to accomplish.
